comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: Monday August 2 also happened in 1897 and 1909. The New Sunday World is a newspaper which existed from 20 June and 17 October 1897, if wikipedia is to be believed: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunday_World_ So the picture is from 1897 or later.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: this won't be much help, but it was called the Singer Manufacturing Company from 1865 onwards. The Phoenix Brewery built an ale plant in 1895, but was bought by Guinness in 1905. Manders went belly up in 1883, see simtec.us/dublinbrewing/history.html

comment.author: 40089693@N07
comment._content: I just realized staring for a few minutes how large these posters are after noticing the horse drawn carriages! I wonder if they come from the same or multiple print factories???

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: Mixed marriages between Catholic and Protestant ( very much frowned on)

comment.author: 33672515@N05
comment._content: I haven't a clue about dates but I love the Singer sewing machines poster girl - "106 years old (taken from life)".  Must get a crank handle put on my sewing machine.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Giuseppe's the carts and donkeys were quite small.  If you look at the man in the original of the shot you will see just how small?  The thing about these posters is that they could have been up there for days/weeks/months/years and the condition of some posters would indicate years.

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: I think it is clear that the picture wasn't taken before June 1897, because of the advertisement for the New Sunday World. The question remaining is when was the latest possible date the picture was taken. As regards to Manders brewery, this book: books.google.nl/books?id=pgWPrxwoI2cC&lpg=PA27&ot... suggests that Manders & Powell (a result of a merger?) merged with Phoenix in 1890, but that it had gone bust before WW I, that is compliant with the 1905 takeover by Guinness quoted above. As we have a hard date of June 1897, it is clear the Manders and Phoenix were still available as seperate brews/brands in 1897, even after they joined forces. The damage to the posters only give an indication, no hard date. The general humidity of the Irish climate might lead to early damage to the posters. But given the "newness" of the New Sunday World and Irish Rosary posters, I would say that the latest date would be 1898.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Sorry, chaps (and chapettes), just getting down to business now. Found the Irish Rosary on our shelves and there, in all its glory, is the article on Mixed Marriages in the July 1897 issue. Here's a flavour of it: "... That sympathetic attraction which unites one soul with another is out of the question between a Catholic and a Protestant. We may be very fond of those who are not one with us in faith, very intimate with them up to a certain point, but there is always an imperceptible barrier between us, a gulf which no amount of affection is capable of bridging over ... it follows that when husband and wife are at variance upon the most important subject of all, their faith, a unity of tastes and feelings in other matters will count for very little in the sum total..."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
I agree with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] that the latest date would probably be 1898. I'm puting that here (hedging my bets with "circa"), and on the "whole" photo of Patrick Street.
As this is a democratic forum, are we all (more or less) in agreement before I amend the metadata for this photo on our library catalogue?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
